title: Probing Atomic Structure and Excitons in 2D Heterostructures Through Cryogenic STEM-EELS
content: The exploration of two-dimensional (2D) materials and the ability to engineer atomically thin heterostructures have opened a fascinating platform for tailoring novel material properties and uncovering exotic quantum phenomena. Vertical stacking of atomically thin 2D materials, such as transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), with a lattice difference/rotational alignment result in the formation of a moiré lattice, often inducing new properties not present in individual layers [1]. For example, the emergence of tunable Mott insulators [2], unconventional superconductivity [3], moiré trapped valley excitons [4, 5] and recent observation of the fractional quantum anomalous Hall effect in twisted MoTe2 [6] have been revealed in such heterostructures. Control of the relative twist angle allows manipulation of interlayer interactions and the emergence of excitons, strongly bound electron-hole pairs localized by periodic moiré potentials.
